journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Vibroacoustic response and active control of a fluid-filled functionally graded piezoelectric material composite cylinder

contrib-group.aff: Acoustics Research Laboratory, School of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Seyyed M Hasheminejad, Acoustics Research Laboratory, School of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak, Tehran 16846-13114, Iran. Email: hashemi@iust.ac.ir

abstract.p: The linear three-dimensional piezoelasticity theory in conjunction with the versatile transfer matrix approach is employed to investigate the steady-state nonaxisymmetric fluid–structure-coupled vibrations of an arbitrarily thick bilaminate simply supported hollow cylinder of finite length, composed of an inner layer of orthotropic functionally graded material perfectly bonded to an outer layer of radially/axially/circumferentially polarized functionally graded piezoceramic material. The cylinder is filled with a compressible nonviscous fluid and may be subjected to arbitrary time-harmonic on-surface mechanical drives. The analytical results are illustrated with numerical examples in which water-filled homogeneous PZT4–steel composite cylinders are driven by harmonic external concentrated or distributed radial surface loads. When the outer piezoelectric layer is operating in the receiving (sensing) mode, the frequency spectrums of the induced voltage, stress components, and on-axis acoustic pressure are calculated and discussed for the selected loading configurations. Also, when the piezolayer operates in the active vibration mode, the effects of polarization direction and number of control modes on the voltage required for partial or complete cancellation of the on-axis internal pressure are investigated. Limiting cases are considered, and the validity of results is established by comparison with the data in the existing literature as well as with the aid of a commercial finite element package.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Among different shell geometries, the dynamic behavior of cylindrical shell structure is the subject of modern research, as it has been widely used as the basic element in various types of engineering structures (Leissa, 1973). In numerous practical engineering applications, cylindrical shells are coupled with internal or external fluids (e.g. nuclear reactors, pressure vessels, compressor shells, aircraft fuselage, liquid propellant/storage tanks, submersible vehicles/vessels, and piping systems). Conventional coupled vibration of circular cylindrical shells filled with ideal liquid or submerged in an infinite liquid region has been extensively investigated (Chen et al., 2004a; Hasheminejad and Ahamdi-Savadkoohi, 2010; Shah et al., 2011; Ventsel et al., 2010). Nevertheless, these structures generally do not have sufficient amount of damping, which make them vulnerable when severe resonance occurs. Traditional structural vibration control methods use passive constrained layer damping (PCLD) materials (i.e. a viscoelastic core layer along with an elastic material layer) bonded to the structure’s surface in order to suppress the vibration and noise. The dynamic characteristics of fluid-filled cylindrical shells with viscoelastic damping layers have been studied by several authors. For example, Ramasamy and Ganesan (1999) used the first-order deformation theory to develop a semianalytical FEM model for calculating the natural frequencies and dynamic response of fluid-filled orthotropic cylindrical shells fully covered with constrained layer damping (CLD). Effects of the fluid height, ratio of core to facing thickness and facing fiber orientation on the natural frequencies, and loss factors of cylindrical shells were studied, and it was concluded that added damping treatment may not be beneficial to damp out the earthquake motion. However, massive computation time was consumed due to a large number of elements used in the liquid domain. Hu and Huang (2000) developed a linear sandwich shell theory and used the linear potential flow approach to explore the applications of a CLD treatment to free vibrations of cylindrical shells conveying fluid. They found that fluid loading decreases natural frequencies, and the fluid flow bifurcates each frequency into forward and backward traveling waves, particularly at higher flow velocities. Also, the modal damping imposed by CLD was found to be highly dependent on the longitudinal wave numbers, and the damping factors ultimately reached steady values as the longitudinal wave numbers were increased. Saravanan et al. (2000) developed a semianalytical finite element for multilayered, doubly curved shells of revolution. The authors used this element to study the vibration and damping characteristics of multilayered, cylindrical, fluid-filled shells with alternating layers of elastic and viscoelastic materials. The effect of tank size, boundary conditions, and liquid fill height on the energy dissipation distribution in the shell was investigated for various circumferential and axial modes. Subsequently, this information was used to increase the modal loss factors by redistribution of the viscoelastic core material across the thickness of the shell. Krishna and Ganesan (2007) proposed a generalized semianalytical method for the frequency analysis of conventional viscoelastic fluid-filled shells that preclude the discretization of liquid domain in order to reduce the computation time. The authors expressed the pressure in the fluid domain with Bessel functions and treated the viscoelastic shell domain using finite element discretization based on first-order shear deformation theory. They found that for shells with axial fiber orientation, the fluid added mass effect is less for lower circumferential modes and increases for higher circumferential modes. Also, for shells with circumferential fiber orientation, the added mass effect is more prevalent than shells with axial fibers. However, since the viscoelastic and the host layer were still discretized by finite elements with low-order shape functions, the dynamic response of the sandwich shell in the high-frequency range could be imprecise. Yuan et al. (2009) employed the thin shell theory assumptions along with the linear potential flow theory to derive a first-order integrated differential matrix equation for coupled transient response analysis of a fluid-filled circular cylindrical shell with partially PCLD treatment subjected to ground motion for different boundary conditions. Just recently, Xiang et al. (2011a) subsequently presented a matrix method for coupled free vibration analysis of a liquid-filled circular cylindrical shell with partially CLD treatment. The method consists of treating liquid domain with Bessel functions and the shell domain with transfer matrix equation based on a new set of first-order matrix differential equation. The authors demonstrated the advantages of their approach by making comparisons with the finite element method. Their numerical results show that viscoelastic material (VEM) thickness, coverage ratio, and location of the PCLD have very different effects on the system damping characteristics.

Controlling the response of elastic structures with external or internal fluid loading by passive methods can be a difficult task to achieve due to the coupling between the structure and the fluid. Recent development of intelligent materials has provided an effective way to solve the shape and vibration control problem of complex structural systems. For example, the coupled electromechanical properties of piezoelectric layers embedded onto structures enable them to transform electrical energy to mechanical energy and vice versa, making them well suited for use as distributed sensors and actuators with a broad range of practical applications in noise and vibration control (Hasheminejad and Rajabi, 2008). Relatively, few authors have investigated the active response control of fluid-filled cylindrical shells. Among them, Brevart and Fuller (1993) proposed a control approach based on the feedforward quadratic optimal theory to reduce the total power propagation along fluid-filled elastic cylindrical shells through minimization of the radial displacement of the shell wall at discrete locations downstream of control line forces, which are radially applied to the structure. The authors used the difference of total power flow through the system before and after control to evaluate the impact of the fluid on the performance of the control approach. They found that for the breathing circumferential mode (n = 0), the fluid coupling decreases the control performance when the disturbance is a structural type incident wave, while considerable cutback of the transmitted power flow can be achieved when the disturbance is a fluid-type incident wave with the near-field pressure concentrated near the shell boundary. For the beam mode (n = 1); on the other hand, although the control is applied to the structure, the fluid increases the control performances below the first acoustic cutoff frequency and decreases it above this frequency. Ding et al. (1997) represented three-dimensional (3D) displacement functions and the electric potential with orthogonal Bessel series to study the free vibration equation of simply supported fluid-filled piezoelectric cylindrical shells. Chen et al. (2004b) studied the coupled vibration of an orthotropic functionally graded piezoelectric material (FGPM) hollow cylinder filled with internal compressible fluid using the 3D equations of piezoelasticity. Zhang et al. (2005, 2006) employed the Mindlin plate theory, governing equations of linear piezoelectricity, and the fluid dynamic equations for an ideal and incompressible fluid along with the Golla–Hughes–McTavish (GHM) model for viscoelastic materials for the finite element modeling of a fluid-filled moderately thick cylindrical shell with active constrained layer damping (ACLD). The authors compared their numerical simulation results with experiments and demonstrated the accuracy of the proposed modeling method. ACLD treatments are designed to merge the simplicity and reliability of passive damping with the light weight and high efficiency of active actuators in order to attain high damping over a broad frequency band. Liu et al. (2008) used state subspace identification method to identify the modal parameters of a fluid-filled prismatic shell with hybrid ACLD treatments and subsequently established a state-space model for the design of active control laws. Experiments were conducted to demonstrate the validity and efficiency of ACLD treatments when the fluid-filled prismatic shell is subjected to random and impulse excitations. Jin and Zhang (2010) presented a numerical study on active control of the fluid–structure coupled vibrations of an infinite fluid-filled elastic cylindrical shell excited by an internal acoustic source. The authors used the radial force acting on the shell as the control input, and the radial displacements downstream of the control input are chosen as the error signals. Three control strategies were employed based on different numbers/positions of control forces and error sensors. Just recently, Xiang et al. (2011b) employed the extended homogeneous capacity precision integration approach along with the superposition principle to offer a semianalytic solution for the previously derived electric fluid–solid-coupled governing equations associated with a liquid-filled circular cylindrical shell treated with PACLD layers and subjected to ground harmonic motion. The authors demonstrated that the PACLD can reduce the vibration effectively under a suitable control of voltage distribution through some numerical examples. Also, Larbi and Deü (2011) presented a 3D exact mixed state-space solution for the free vibration analysis of simply supported arbitrarily thick radially polarized piezoceramic hollow cylinders, completely filled with an inviscid and compressible fluid.

The above review indicates that while there exists a notable number of (relatively few) researchers who consider controlling the response of fluid-filled thin or moderately thick cylindrical shell structures with PCLD/ACLD treatments, there seems to be no rigorous analysis on the forced vibration and/or active vibration control of fluid-filled hollow piezolaminate cylinders of arbitrary wall thickness. Thus, in this article, we employ the normal mode expansion method, the Fourier series expansion in the circumferential direction along with the powerful transfer matrix solution technique to present an exact 3D analysis for steady-state forced vibration response of a finite length, thick-walled composite piezolaminate (FGPM–FGM) hollow cylinder, filled with an inviscid ideal compressible fluid, and subjected to arbitrary time-harmonic radial/transverse surface driving loads. The proposed model is of academic interest basically due to its inherent value as a canonical problem in structural acoustics. The presented results can provide a theoretical basis for dynamic response control of fluid–structure coupled intelligent cylindrical structure. It is of practical value for structural acoustic engineers involved in the dynamic analysis and design of fluid-loaded thick-walled FGM cylindrical shells, tubes, or pipelines, where the classical theories for shells usually become inaccurate and even invalid, with possible applications in chemical industries, nuclear power plants, marine structures, pipelines, and submarine and offshore installations (Chen et al., 2003; Hopkins, 1995). The presented accurate solution can complement the general research on a wide class of fluid–structure dynamic control problems such as control of launch vehicle payload fairing internal acoustics (Niezrecki and Cudney, 2001), prediction of the dynamic response of thick cylindrical shells excited by surface-bonded piezoelectric actuators (Lalande et al., 1995), and narrowband active structural acoustic control of sound radiation into a rigidly capped finite cylinder (Clark and Fuller, 1994; Lester and Lefebvre, 1993). It can also serve as the benchmark for comparison to solutions obtained by strictly numerical or asymptotic approaches.

sec.title: Formulation
sec.p: We consider the problem of a simply supported bilaminate hollow cylinder of finite length, L, composed of an inner orthotropic FGM layer of total thickness h=aq−a0, perfectly bonded to an outer layer of FGPM of total thickness H=aq+s−aq, which is polarized in axial, radial, or circumferential direction. The hollow cylinder is assumed to be filled with an ideal compressible acoustic fluid and may be subjected to radial or transverse external time-harmonic loads at its outer or inner boundary (see Figure 1; note that only the external distributed normal and transverse loads (fr,fθ) are shown in the figure for simplicity).

sec.title: Global transfer matrices for the orthotropic FGM and FGPM layers
sec.p: The generalized constitutive relations for the outer FGPM layer in the cylindrical coordinate system (see Figure 1) may be written as (Ding and Chen, 2001)

where Σij and Γij are the stress and strain components, respectively; Er=∂ϕ/∂r, Eθ=∂ϕ/r∂θ, and Ez=∂ϕ/∂z are the electric intensity in the r, θ, and z directions, respectively; ϕ(r,θ,z,ω) is the electric potential; Cij(r),eij(r) denote the radially dependent elastic and piezoelectric constants, respectively, where it should be noted that regardless of direction of polarized, there are only five nonzero piezoelectric constants. Also, the strain components are related to the material displacement components in the r, θ, and z directions by
Furthermore, the governing equations, in the absence of body forces, are written as (Ding and Chen, 2001)

where ρP(r) is the material density of functionally graded piezoelectric material, Qf is the free charge density, and the electric displacement vector components are written in the form (Yu et al., 2009)
where εij(r) is the dielectric constant.

Now, by employing the appropriate normal mode expansions for the simply supported cylinder, while keeping in mind that at z=0, L, one considers ϕ=Dr=Dθ=0 for radial or circumferential polarization and Dz=0 for axial polarization (Ding and Chen, 2001), the state vector, Y=[UrUθUzΣrrΣrθΣrzDrϕ]T, may be expanded in terms of unknown modal coefficients

where g(x)=cosx for axial polarization, and g(x)=sinx for radial or circumferential polarization. Following the state-space approach (Ding and Chen, 2001), the state equation can be readily derived by direct substitution of the constitutive relations (1), (2), (4), and (5) into relation (3) and utilizing the orthogonality of trigonometric functions in the form

where Vnm=[UrnmUθnmUznmΣrrnmΣrθnmΣrznmDrnmϕnm]T is the modal state vector, and Dnm(r,ω) is a 8×8 modal coefficient matrix whose elements are given in Appendix 1. Once the modal state vector is obtained, one can readily use relations (1) and (2) to find the relevant hoop and axial stress components, as presented at the end of Appendix 1.

Direct solution of equation (6) is very difficult, as the elements of Dnm are not constants. Hence, by adopting a laminate model (Ding and Chen, 2001), the FPGM cylindrical layer may be assumed to be composed of s-sublayers of equal thickness, hs=(aq+s−aq)/s, which are perfectly bonded at their interfaces and lined up such that their axes of symmetry coincide with each other. As the thickness of each sublayer is supposed to be very small, the coefficient matrix Dnm can advantageously be assumed constant within each sublayer, where we shall use its value at the middle radius of the kth sublayer (i.e. we take Dnm(r¯k), in which r¯k=(rk+rk−1)/2 and rk=aq+khs;k=1,2,…,s). Furthermore, adopting the simple rule of mixture to describe the distribution of material properties through the thickness of FGPM layer (Yu et al., 2009), one has

where VP(r¯k) is the volume fraction of the “inner” material in the kth layer of the FGPM layer; (Cijin,ρPin) and (Cijout,ρPout) are the elastic coefficients and mass density of inner and outer constituting FGPM materials, respectively; and (eijin,εijin) and (eijout,εijout) represent the piezoelectric/dielectric constants of the inner and outer FGPM materials, respectively. Thus, within the kth sublayer, the solution to equation (6) can be written as
where rk−1=[aq+(k−1)hs]≤r≤rk=(aq+khs). Subsequent evaluation of equation (7) at the outer surface of the kth sublayer leads to the following useful recurrence relation

which relates the state variables at the outer surface of the kth sublayer to those at the inner surface. Finally, by invoking the continuity conditions between all interface layers, the state variables at the outer radius of the FGPM layer (i.e. at r=aq+s) are advantageously related to those at the inner radius (i.e. at r=aq) via a 8×8 global modal transfer matrix Tnm by
where Tnm=Πk=1sexp[hsDnm(r¯k,ω)].

For the inner orthotropic FGM layer, one can readily follow the above procedure to drive the pertinent global transfer matrix. In particular, the modal state-space equation (6) is rewritten as dvnm/dr=dnmvnm, in which vnm=[urnmuθnmuznmσrrnmσrθnmσrznm]T is the modal state vector and dnm(r,ω) is a 6×6 modal coefficient matrix whose elements are given in Appendix 2. Once the modal state vector is obtained, one can easily find the hoop and axial stress components (σθθ,σzz), as presented at the end of Appendix 2. Next, assuming the orthotropic FGM layer to be composed of q-sublayers of equal thickness, hq=(aq−a0)/q, which are perfectly bonded at their interfaces and lined up such that their axes of symmetry coincide with each other, the latter modal state-space equation be solved to yield the corresponding global transfer matrix in the form tnm=Πk=1qexp[hqdnm(r¯k,ω)], in which tnm is a 6×6 matrix. Furthermore, the relevant elastic constants, cij(r), and mass density, ρO(r), within the kth layer of inner radius rk−1 and outer radius rk and uniform thickness hq may be described by the simple rule of mixture as (Yu et al., 2009)

sec.title: Acoustic field equations
sec.p: Following the standard methods of theoretical acoustics, the field equation for the inner inviscid and ideal compressible medium may be expressed in terms of the acoustic pressure as (Pierce, 1991)
in the finite cylindrical domain defined by 0≤r≤a0, −π≤θ≤π, and 0≤z≤L, where k=ω/c is the acoustic wave number and c is the speed of the sound. Also, the fluid displacement vector is written as
where ρ is the fluid density, ∇ is the gradient operator, and the internal acoustic pressure field may be expanded in terms of unknown modal coefficients in the form (Axisa and Antunes, 2006)
where

in which K=k2−(πm/L)2, and Jn and In denote the standard and modified cylindrical Bessel functions of the first kind, respectively. Using equation (11), the radial component of fluid displacement is written as
where Qnm=2ρω2Pnm/P′nm, and “prime” denotes differentiation with respect to the radial coordinate.

sec.title: Boundary conditions and the final global transfer matrix
sec.p: The applied external radial and transverse loads applied at the inner/outer surfaces of the hollow cylinder (see Figure 1) may respectively be expanded in the form
where
Also, the open- or short-circuited electrical boundary conditions for the FGPM layer are written as (Adelman et al., 1976)

By incorporating the perfect bonding condition at the interface between orthotropic FGM and FGPM layers (i.e. at r=aq) in our state-space formulation, the modal state variable vector at the inner radius of the orthotropic FGM layer (r=a0), augmented with the relevant electrical state variables at the inner surface of the FGPM layer (r=aq), may advantageously be related to those at the outer radius of the FGPM layer (r=aq+s) via a 8×8 global transfer matrix, Snm, as

in which Snm=[Tnm(:,1:6)tnm;Tnm(:,7:8)] and Xnm=[vnmT(a0,ω),Drnm(aq,ω),ϕnm(aq,ω)]T, where it should be noted that Tnm(:,1:6) contains only the first six columns of Tnm, while Tnm(:,7:8) contains only the last two columns of Tnm.
The appropriate (mechanical) boundary conditions that should be imposed at the inner and the outer surfaces of the multilayered FGM and FGPM layers are as follows:

list-item.p: – Vanishing of the tangential stress components at the inner/outer surfaces in z-direction
– Equality of the tangential stress and applied external transverse load at the inner/outer surfaces
– Equality of the normal stress and applied external normal load at the outer surface
– Equilibrium of the radial stress with the applied external radial load and fluid pressure at the inner surface
– Continuity of the normal fluid and solid displacements at the inner surface

sec.p: By direct substitution of mechanical boundary conditions (17) into (16) for short-circuit boundary condition, after some algebra, one obtains
and for open-circuit condition, equation (16) yields

Numerical solution of the above systems of equations leads to determination of all displacement and stress components in the composite cylinder. Also, by proper selection of the modal voltage coefficient ϕnm, one can impose a complete cancellation of the modal coefficients for the transmitted pressure. Consequently, for complete cancellation or control of the coefficients for the transmitted pressure (i.e. by setting Pnm(a0,ω)=urnm(a0,ω)=0), the linear system (18a) may advantageously be rewritten in the form
where we have set ϕnm(aq,ω)=0. Thus, equation (19) can readily be solved for the modal electrical voltage coefficient, ϕnm(aq+s), required for complete annihilation of Pnm.

sec.title: Numerical results
sec.p: In this section, we consider some numerical examples. Realizing the large number of parameters involved here while keeping in view our computing hardware limitations, we confine our attention to a particular model. To simulate a practical situation in a chemical or reactor vessel, the filling fluid is assumed to be water at 75∘C(ρ=975kg/m3,c=1500m/s). The inner/outer radius, the total thickness, and length of the bilaminate cylinder are supposed to be constant (a0=0.98m,aq=1m,aq+s=1.02m; h = H = 0.02 m; L = 4 m). For simplicity, the outer layer is assumed to be fabricated from homogenous PZT4 while the inner layer is taken to be stainless steel, with the relevant material properties are as given in Tables 1 and 2. Also, two types of external loads are considered (see Figure 1):

caption.p: Elastic constants for the outer piezoelectric and inner elastic layers.
Piezoelectric and dielectric constants for the PZT4 layer.

sec.p: Uniformly distributed radial load (subtended angle α, length d)
where by using second of equation (14b), one obtains
Concentrated radial load (acting on θ=0,z=L/2)
where frnm(ω)=f0sin(mπ/4)/πLaq+s(N/m2) and p0=f0/αaq+sd.

A general Mathematica code was constructed for computing the global modal transfer matrix, Snm, treating the linear systems of equations (18) and (19) through the use of the built-in command “LinearSolve,” and calculating the unknown modal coefficients as well as the electrical voltage coefficients, ϕnm(aq+s), required for complete annihilation of Pnm, as a function of the excitation frequency. The matrix exponential functions were computed using the Mathematica built-in function “MatrixExp,” and all integrations were performed by employing the command “Integrate.” The computations were performed on a network of personal computer with a maximum number of qmax=smax=30 sublayers, and a maximum truncation constant of nmax, mmax=50, especially selected to assure uniform convergence in case of a thick bilaminate hollow cylinder and also for all loading configurations. The convergence of numerical solutions is secured in a simple trial and error manner, by increasing the number of sublayers as well as the truncation constant (i.e. by including more modes in all summations) while looking for steadiness or stability in the numerical values of the solutions.

Figure 2 displays the dimensionless on-axis acoustic pressure amplitude |p(r=θ=0;0≤z≤L/2;ω)/(f0/aq2)|, versus excitation frequency for the radially/axially/circumferentially polarized open-circuit piezocylinder subjected to an external radial central concentrated or a uniformly distributed radial load (f0=1000N; α=π/2, d = L/2). Here one should note that the axial parameter in the figure varies in the range 0≤(z/aq)≤L/2aq=2 (i.e. from the origin “O” to the center of the cavity; see Figure 1). The most important observations are described in the following. Numerous fluid-coupled structural resonances (very high amplitudes) appear as “white-colored” parallel vertical strips in all the subplots, especially in the moderate to high excitation frequency range. These resonances seem to sharper for the concentrated load in comparison with the distributed load. Increasing the excitation frequency leads to a notable increase in the acoustic pressure amplitudes, regardless of direction of polarization, especially for the concentrated radial load. Also, in the case of distributed radial load, increasing axial parameter (i.e. approaching the cylinder center section or load position) leads to an expected increase in the acoustic pressure amplitudes, almost regardless of direction of polarization. For the concentrated radial load, on the other hand, no special trend can be observed, which may be linked to the fact that for this type of load the higher elastic modes get more seriously involved. Keeping in mind the open-circuit electrical boundary condition (i.e. the outer layer is in the “sensor mode”), the direction of polarization appears to have a small influence on the on-axis pressure distribution. Finally, it should be noted here that the calculated on-axis acoustic pressure is only affected by the axisymmetric (n = 0) modes (see equation (20)).

caption.p: Dimensionless on-axis acoustic pressure amplitude versus excitation frequency for the radially/axially/circumferentially polarized open-circuit piezocylinder subjected to an external radial central concentrated or a uniformly distributed central radial load.

sec.p: Figure 3 shows the angular distribution of dimensionless normal and shear stress amplitudes at the interface between the outer PZT4 and inner steel layers, σrr*=|σrr(r=aq;0≤θ≤π;z=L/2;ω)/(f0/aq2)|,σrθ*=|σrθ(r=aq;0≤θ≤π;z=L/2;ω)/(f0/aq2)|, versus excitation frequency for the radially/axially/circumferentially polarized open-circuit piezocylinder subjected to the external uniformly distributed radial load (f0=1000N; α=π/2, d = L/2). Here again, numerous fluid-coupled structural resonances appear as “white-colored” parallel vertical strips in all the subplots, especially in the moderate to high excitation frequency range, regardless of direction of polarization. The “nonresonant” interface shear stress amplitudes (i.e. the red-colored regions) are about three times the normal stress amplitudes, suggesting a higher chance of shear or torsional slip in comparison with the possibility of normal separation in the off-resonance working condition. Also, it is clear that at very low excitation frequencies, the maximum interface dynamic stress concentrations generally occur immediately beyond the subtending angle of the applied external load (i.e. in the θ>π/4 region), while in the moderate frequency range the stress concentrations appear to shift within the subtending angle (i.e. right under the load in the 0<θ<π/4 region), almost regardless of direction of polarization. In the higher frequency range, however, the directivity patterns become more complex and display a generally periodic pattern with respect to the circumferential coordinate.

caption.p: Angular distribution of dimensionless normal and shear stress amplitudes at the interface between the outer PZT4 and inner steel layers versus excitation frequency for the radially/axially/circumferentially polarized open-circuit piezocylinder subjected to the external uniformly distributed radial load.

sec.p: Figure 4 presents the dimensionless hoop and axial stress frequency spectrums for a selected observation angle (right under the load) and thickness parameters, ξ=(r−a0)/(aq+s−a0), across the cylinder central section, that is, σθθ*=|σθθ(ξ=0,1/3,5/6;θ=0;z=L/2;ω)/(f0/aq2)| and σzz*=|σzz(ξ=0,1/3,5/6;θ=0;z=L/2;ω)/(f0/aq2)|, for the radially/axially/circumferentially polarized open-circuit piezocylinder subjected to the external uniformly distributed radial load (f0=1000N; α=π/2, d = L/2). As expected, except at very low excitation frequencies, the highest amplitudes for the hoop and axial stress components are generally observed at the surface of the inner (steel) layer (i.e. at ξ=0). Also, the observation depth parameter, ξ, has a greater effect on the hoop stress amplitudes in comparison with the axial stress amplitudes (i.e. the axial stress spectrum curves are more packed together in comparison with the hoop stress curves). This may be linked to the higher influence of radial and circumferential waves on the hoop stress variations in comparison with the axial stress values for which the nearly depth-independent axial propagating waves are of importance. Furthermore, while the hoop and axial stress spectrum curves exhibit a very similar behavior at high frequencies, they present distinctive patterns at low and moderate frequencies, almost regardless of direction of polarization. In particular, one may note that the first antiresonances in the ξ=0 hoop stress curves occur beyond 100 Hz (i.e. about f = 115 Hz), while the first antiresonances in the ξ=0 axial stress curves occur considerably before f = 100 Hz (i.e. about f = 80 Hz).

caption.p: Dimensionless hoop and axial stress frequency spectrums across the cylinder central section for the radially/axially/circumferentially polarized open-circuit piezocylinder subjected to the external uniformly distributed radial load.

sec.p: Figure 5 shows the dimensionless cavity center-point acoustic pressure, |p(r=θ=0;z=L/2;ω)/(f0/aq2)|, as well as the sensor voltage amplitude, |ϕ(r=aq+s;θ=5π/6;z=L/4;ω)|, versus excitation frequency for the radially/axially/circumferentially polarized open-circuit piezocylinder subjected to the external uniformly distributed radial load (f0=1000N; α=π/2, d = L/2). Comments very similar to the previous remarks can readily be made. The most important distinctions are described in the following. A simple comparison of peaks (resonances) of solid (pressure) and dashed (voltage) lines indicates that most of the (axisymmetric) centerline pressure modes can readily be sensed in both cases of axially and radially polarized cylinders, while none of these modes appear to be observable in the case of the circumferentially polarized cylinder. This may be linked to the fact that the applied radial external load cannot excite the purely torsional structural modes in the composite cylinder. Furthermore, even if these modes get excited by other types of surface driving forces, they generally are not expected to influence the acoustic pressure modes within the fluid-filled cavity. Consequently, the axially or radially polarized sensor layers appear to be a far better choice for sensing internal fluid acoustic pressure modes in comparison with the circumferentially polarized cylinder. Finally, it should be noted that the first and fourth pressure resonances observed in the first two subplots (i.e. for the axially and radially polarized cylinder) cannot be linked to any corresponding sensor voltage peaks (please note that it is hard to distinguish between the third and the fourth peaks in both of these subplots, as they are very closely located; also note that there is a voltage peak associated with the third structural resonance). Moreover, the first and fourth pressure peaks are further checked through simple frequency response plotting of the modal pressures, Pnm(r,ω) (results are not shown for briefness), to be respectively associated with the (n = 0, m = 1) and (n = 0, m = 5) internal fluid acoustic resonances.

caption.p: Dimensionless cavity center-point acoustic pressure and the sensor voltage amplitude versus excitation frequency for the radially/axially/circumferentially polarized open-circuit piezocylinder subjected to the external uniformly distributed radial load.

sec.p: Figures 6 and 7 present the truncated total axisymmetric (n = 0) voltage amplitude variation along the axially/radially polarized piezocylinder axis, |ϕ(r=aq+s;−π≤θ≤π;z;ω)|, which is required for partial or complete cancellation of the on-axis acoustic pressure, when the cylinder is subjected to the uniformly distributed radial load. Also shown (in the second column) are the resulting modified on-axis pressure amplitudes for the selected sums of mmax=M=1,3,5,11 active modes. Here it should be noted that the circumferentially polarized cylinder is incapable of controlling the axisymmetric pressure modes within the composite cylinder. The most interesting observations are described in the following. Application of the first few cancellation voltage modes (M=1,3) has a relatively small overall effect on the resulting on-axis acoustic pressure amplitudes mainly in the low and moderated frequency range. Summing a progressively larger number of voltage modes (M=5,11) leads to a remarkable improvement in active cancellation of the pressure amplitudes for the intermediate and higher excitation frequencies, nearly regardless of direction of polarization. Also, in the best situation (M = 11), the input voltage amplitude required for effective cancellation of the on-axis pressure amplitude in the axially polarized situation is about 60 times higher than that required for the radially polarized cylinder. This points to the remarkable advantage of the radially polarized actuator for active cancellation of the internal fluid pressure. Furthermore, the appearance of large “white spots” (i.e. voltage saturation) at about f = 475 Hz in the first column subplots indicates that when the piezocylinder is operating in the active vibration mode, application of a remarkably large voltage is required in order to properly suppress the on-axis acoustic pressure variations in this range of excitation frequencies.

caption.p: The truncated total axisymmetric voltage amplitude variation along the axially polarized piezocylinder, required for partial or complete cancellation of the on-axis acoustic pressure, when the cylinder is subjected to the uniformly distributed radial load.

The truncated total axisymmetric voltage amplitude variation along the radially polarized piezocylinder, required for partial or complete cancellation of the on-axis acoustic pressure, when the cylinder is subjected to the uniformly distributed radial load.

sec.p: Finally, in order to demonstrate the overall validity of the work, we first neglected the inner fluid density (ρ=0) and computed the dimensionless mid-cylinder radial surface displacement amplitude, |Ur*|=|Ur(r=aq+s;θ=0;z=L/2;ω)/(f0/aqC11)|, versus the excitation frequency for a very thick and short hollow radially/axially/circumferentially polarized short-circuited thick laminated PZT4–steel cylinder (a0=0.8m,aq=1m,aq+s=1.2m; h = H = 0.2 m; L = 2 m; q = s = 200), subjected to the external uniformly distributed radial load (f0=1000N; α=π/2, d = L/2). The outcome, as shown in Figure 8(a), shows excellent agreements with that calculated using the commercial finite element code ABAQUS (ABAQUS, Analysis User’s Manual). Here, it should be noted that the unrealistic thickness values selected for the PZT4 and steel layers (h = H = 0.2 m) in present validation is merely for sake of demonstrating the special ability of the proposed formulation in modeling extremely thick piezolaminate shells. As a further check, we used our general code to compute the modal displacement frequency response amplitude, |urnm(aq,ω)|, for a water-filled single-layer FGPM (PZT4−Ba2NaNb5O15) cylinder (VP=(r¯k−aq)/hs;s=60;mπaq/L=2;h=0) subjected to concentrated radial and transverse loads at its central section (r=aq+s,θ=0, z = L/2) for selected range of thickness parameters (0≤H/aq≤2). Subsequently, a simple code was written to single out the resonance frequencies for each mode of FGPM cylinder vibration. The computed dimensionless frequencies, Ω=ωaqρPPZT4/C44PZT4, as plotted in Figure 8(b), exhibit perfect agreements with the free vibration natural frequency data presented in Figure 8 of Chen et al. (2004b).

caption.p: (a) Dimensionless mid-cylinder radial surface displacement amplitude versus the excitation frequency for an evacuated radially/axially/circumferentially polarized composite PZT4–steel cylinder subjected to the external uniformly distributed radial load. (b) The first five computed dimensionless natural frequencies of a water-filled FGPM (PZT4–Ba2NaNb5O15) cylinder for selected range of thickness parameters.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The nonaxisymmetric acoustic wave radiation and active sound cancellation within a radially/axially/circumferentially polarized, simply supported, fluid-filled bilaminate PZT4/steel cylindrical vessel, driven by concentrated or distributed harmonic surface loads, is considered. The most important observations are summarized as follows:

list-item.p: Increasing the excitation frequency (axial parameter) leads to a notable increase in the acoustic pressure amplitudes, regardless of direction of polarization, especially for the concentrated (distributed) radial load. Also, the calculated on-axis acoustic pressure is observed to be only affected by the axisymmetric structural modes.

In the off-resonance working condition, the PZT4/steel interface shear stress amplitudes are about three times the corresponding normal stress amplitudes, implying a higher likelihood of torsional slip in comparison with the possibility of normal separation.

At very low excitation frequencies, the maximum interface dynamic stress concentrations generally occur immediately beyond the subtending angle of the applied external distributed load, while in the moderate frequency range the stress concentrations appear to shift within the subtending angle, almost regardless of direction of polarization.

The highest amplitudes for the hoop and axial stress components are generally observed at the inner surface of the composite cylinder. Also, the observation depth parameter has a greater effect on the hoop stress amplitudes in comparison with the axial stress amplitudes, which is linked to the higher influence of radial and circumferential waves on the hoop stress variations in comparison with the axial stress values for which the nearly depth-independent axial propagating waves are of importance.

Most of the (axisymmetric) pressure modes can readily be sensed in cases of axially or radially polarized composite cylinders, while none are observable in case of circumferential polarization, which is related to the incapability of the applied radial external load to excite the purely torsional structural modes. Consequently, the axially or radially polarized sensor layers are found to be a far better choice for sensing internal fluid acoustic pressure modes in comparison with the circumferentially polarized cylinder.

When the cylinder is working in the active vibration mode, application of a progressively larger number of active voltage modes leads to a remarkable improvement in cancellation of the acoustic pressure amplitudes for the intermediate and higher excitation frequencies, nearly regardless of direction of polarization (axial/radial), keeping in mind the possibility of actuator voltage saturation in the vicinity of important structural resonance frequencies.

The circumferentially polarized cylinder is incapable of controlling the axisymmetric pressure modes within the composite cylinder. Also, the input voltage amplitude required for effective cancellation of the pressure amplitudes in the axially polarized situation is considerably higher than that required for the radially polarized cylinder, suggesting the remarkable advantage of the radially polarized actuator for active cancellation of the internal fluid pressure.

sec.p: The presented exact 3D analysis provides a unified theoretical basis for investigating the nonaxisymmetric steady-state forced vibration response and/or active vibroacoustic control of a finite length (simply supported), fluid-filled, radially/axially/circumferentially polarized piezolaminate (FGPM–FGM) hollow cylinder of arbitrary wall thickness, subjected to arbitrary time-harmonic radial/transverse surface driving loads.
